import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import Markdown
test_csv = pd.read_csv("test_csv.csv")
Markdown(test_csv.to_markdown(index=False))

title: Notebook
text:
Polar Axis
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis







Code
df=pd.DataFrame([[1,2,3],[4,5,6],[7,8,9]], columns=['a', 'b', 'c'])
df

title: Notebook
text:
Latest stock values for analysis

We are using values from IBEX ticker values (Spanish stock values) every Friday - Closing
These are the lates values we used for our analysis.

plot_sample_data(path='arima_fitted_data.csv', column='Close')

title: Notebook
text:
Test over last 8 weeks

We keep data from last 8 weeks ‘unseen’ by our arima model. 
This means that the model doesn’t know the last 8 values. The hypothetical present of our model is 8 weeks in the past. 
In that hypothetical present, if we could see the future we would see the last 8 weeks.



Code
table_horizontal(path='arima_fitted_data.csv', column='Close', display_weeks=16)

title: Notebook
section: Plot real vales vs model output and confidence intervals
text:
Plot real vales vs model output and confidence intervals
This is a plot of the real values (in blue) and the model output (in green) and the confident intervals (in red)


Code
plot_fit_and_forecast(path='arima_fitted_data.csv', column='Close', display_weeks=16)
